Description: Fragment of an Attic black-figured pottery open vase, perhaps a cup; very flat profile; glazed inside with tondo reserved and seemingly decorated. Outside, from centre: thin rays; band of alternating black and reserved tongues between triple lines; frieze with two figures preserved, a female facing right to a gesturing male, with vine spray in background; further object overlapping the bands at top right.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

This is a curious piece. It can scarcely be a lid with a tondo on the underside, but if it is a cup or plate the frieze is 'upside-down' - not unknown on Kassel/Droop cups, though the sherd may be too flat for such a shape.
Bibliographic references: Robinson 1893 / Catalogue of Greek, Etruscan and Roman Vases (p. 234, no. 201)
Fairbanks 1928 / Early Vases preceding Athenian Black Figure Ware (p. 127, no. 354.5, pl. XXXVIII)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.1572)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.4778 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
